title: How has the proportion of social care users who feel safe changed?
analysis_commentary:
The Personal Adult Social Care Survey asks how safe service users feel in their general lives, where safety is defined in the questionnaire as “feeling safe both inside and outside the home. This includes fear of abuse, falling or other physical harm and fear of being attacked or robbed”. Users can answer: 'I feel as safe as I want', 'Generally I feel adequately safe, but not as safe as I would like', 'I feel less than adequately safe' or 'I don't feel safe at all'.

Here, we report only on those who felt as safe as they wanted to. The proportion of people who felt as safe as they wanted to increased from 62.4% in 2010/11 to 63.8% in 2012/13; an increase of 1.4%. However as the data in 2010/11 is un-weighted it is more appropriate to look at the 1.2% increase from 2011/12 to 2012/13. Despite the improvements, there were still roughly 35% who didn't feel as safe as they wanted to in 2012-13.
data_source: Health & Social Care Information Centre, Personal Adult Social Care Survey
